awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a New X-Ray Diffractometer to Advance Research and Education in Primarily Undergraduate/Minority Serving Institutions within the District of Columbia
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs to support and improve research by Dr. Xueqing Song and colleagues Lei Wang, Ozlem Dilek, Uche Udeochu and Alexandra Taraboletti. This institution is acquiring a single crystal X-ray difffractometer (SCXRD). In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, geology and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this Historically Black College and University (HBCU) as well as the other institution in the DC area such as the Catholic University of America, American University, Gallaudet University and Trinity Washington University. The instrumentation provides direct research experience for students in a variety of courses distributed in various departments. A one-week summer institute is designed to provide UDC and partner institutions formal and hands-on training in crystallography.

The award of the X-ray diffractometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The science enabled by this instrument provides relevant societal benefits by associating biofunctional and structural studies of the metalloenzymatic targets of the copper chelator cuprizone that inhibits monoamine oxidase and causes liver and brain damage and by exploring interfacial phenomena of materials and structure-activity dynamics of biologically significant compounds. The instrumentation is also used for studying interactions between triorganotin complexes and thiol containing protease and fluorescent probes for imaging oxidative stress-induced lipid peroxidation products of macrophages. The diffractometer is also employed to carry out investigations of spin crossover complexes and regolith-based geopolymerization for in-situ resource utilization. The instrument also serves researchers studying antibacterial, antiviral agents and lipoprotein metabolism modulators and those analyzing mineral precipitation techniques for biomediated ground improvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of the District of Columbia (UDC) has introduced its first X-ray Diffractometer (XRD) with the support of a National Science Foundation (NSF) Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant. This new XRD system represents a significant advancement in research and teaching, addressing a critical need for advanced crystallography techniques that are often underrepresented at the undergraduate level. The acquisition of the XRD has substantially expanded UDC’s capabilities in modern materials research and STEM education, benefiting not only UDC but also a wider network of academic partners, including Catholic University of America, American University, Gallaudet University, and Trinity Washington University.

Intellectual Merit

Crystallography, the study of crystal structures, is a foundational technique in chemistry, physics, and materials science. The new XRD has enhanced UDC’s capacity to conduct cutting-edge research in these fields, enabling faculty and students to explore complex materials and chemical structures. Specifically, the XRD supports research on:

  • Ionic organotin complexes (Dr. Song and students, UDC): Providing insights into molecular structures that have potential applications in materials science and environmental chemistry.
  • Mineral precipitation techniques (Dr. Azam and students, UDC): Aiming to reduce ammonia production, a major environmental concern.
  • SnO₂-based perovskite solar cells (Dr. Dang and students, UDC): Exploring new materials for energy-efficient solar cells.
  • Spin-crossover behavior in iron(II) complexes (Dr. Brews, Catholic University): Investigating the temperature-dependent switching between low- and high-spin states, which has implications for magnetic materials and molecular electronics.

Over the course of the award, the XRD has supported five research publications and six conference presentations, all co-authored by students. These contributions highlight the XRD's role in advancing research in chemistry and materials science.

Broader Impacts

The acquisition of the XRD has had a profound impact on STEM education and research at UDC and its partner institutions. A key goal of this project was to expand access to advanced scientific instrumentation for underrepresented and minority-serving institutions (MSIs). By sharing the XRD with institutions such as Gallaudet University and Trinity Washington University, which previously lacked access to such equipment, the project has broadened research opportunities for diverse student populations.

Key educational outcomes include:

  • Curriculum Development: UDC’s chemistry curriculum has been updated to incorporate crystallography into courses such as Descriptive Inorganic Chemistry, Organic Chemistry, Advanced Inorganic Chemistry, and Biochemistry. Topics such as crystal growth, data collection, and structure elucidation are now integral parts of the program, exposing students to techniques critical for careers in modern science.
  • Student Training: Training was provided to 15 potential crystallography users, including five undergraduate chemistry majors and five graduate students, along with faculty from UDC’s College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) and School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS). Gallaudet University students also received specialized training in crystallography, promoting cross-institutional collaboration.
  • Outreach and Recruitment: Through a collaboration with Howard University and NSF’s ChemMatCARS, UDC secured an NSF PREC Planning Proposal aimed at recruiting more students into UDC’s undergraduate chemistry program and Howard’s graduate chemistry program. This partnership included a 2-day workshop on crystallography for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as formal training for faculty.
  • High School Engagement: UDC partnered with the American Chemical Society (ACS) Project SEED program to engage high school students in research. Two high school students conducted summer research in UDC’s crystallography lab, with one earning first place in a poster presentation.

Additionally, the success of the XRD grant paved the way for UDC to apply for and secure the prestigious Beckman Scholars Program, an undergraduate research initiative supported by the Arnold & Mabel Beckman Foundation. This program will further elevate the research experience of UDC’s chemistry students by providing funding and mentorship for hands-on research.

Summary of Project Outcomes

This NSF MRI grant has had a transformative impact on UDC’s research and teaching infrastructure. The acquisition of the XRD system has enabled UDC faculty and students to conduct cutting-edge research in chemistry, materials science, and environmental science. The system has been instrumental in producing five research publications and six conference presentations, all involving student co-authors.

Educationally, the XRD has allowed UDC to update its chemistry curriculum, providing students with practical experience in crystallography, a technique crucial to modern scientific inquiry. Over 15 potential crystallography users, including undergraduate and graduate students, faculty, and students from partner institutions, have received training on the new system. Outreach efforts, such as workshops, collaborative research, and partnerships with local high schools, have expanded the reach of this project, fostering scientific curiosity and research opportunities for underrepresented groups.

Overall, this project demonstrates how access to advanced scientific instrumentation can enhance both research and education, particularly at minority-serving institutions, and contribute to the broader goals of increasing diversity and inclusion in STEM fields.
